title: 108_hr5319
content: The "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property upon subsequent purchase of renewable energy property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows taxpayers to defer gain from selling real property in the US if they purchase renewable energy property within a specified period. The "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows taxpayers to defer gain from selling real property in the US if they purchase renewable energy property. Gain is recognized when the price for which real property is sold exceeds the cost of the renewable energy property acquired. The "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows taxpayers to defer gain from selling real property in the US if they purchase renewable energy property, which uses renewable energy sources for electricity generation or fuel production. Special rules apply to partnerships and corporations involved in renewable energy activities. The "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows taxpayers to defer gain from selling real property in the US if they purchase renewable energy property. Special rules apply to organizations subject to section 521 or subchapter T. The replacement period is a 2-year period after the sale of real property with an election under subsection (a). Property must be identified during this period. The taxpayer must identify any property to be received in an exchange within 180 days after transferring the relinquished property. The basis of renewable energy property is the same as the exchanged property, adjusted for money received and gains or losses recognized. The taxpayer must identify property for exchange within 180 days. Gain on disposal of renewable energy property is recognized if not previously recognized. Exceptions apply after taxpayer's death. The taxpayer must identify property for exchange within 180 days. Gain on disposal of renewable energy property is recognized if not previously recognized, except in cases of death, compulsory conversion, or tax avoidance purposes. If a taxpayer sells renewable energy property and elects nonrecognition of gain, the IRS has 3 years to assess any deficiency after being notified by the taxpayer of the cost of purchasing the property and intention not to purchase. The IRS has 3 years to assess a deficiency if a taxpayer sells renewable energy property and elects nonrecognition of gain, even if the taxpayer does not purchase replacement property within that time frame. The IRS has 3 years to assess a deficiency if a taxpayer sells renewable energy property and elects nonrecognition of gain. This includes property acquired under section 1046, with a new paragraph added for clarification. Effective December 31, 2004, nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property applies to subsequent purchase of renewable energy property.
